DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY CONTRIBUTORY SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 2 February.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill amends the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948 and the Superannuation Laws Amendment Act 1994. The main purpose of the amendments is to improve the operation of the provisions which allow certain former members and senators who re-enter parliament to repay lump sums paid under the parliamentary contributory superannuation scheme and receive recognition of prior parliamentary service for future benefit purposes.

PARA.TAB: The existing provisions of the scheme allow former members of the scheme who have not qualified for pension benefits, and who received lump sum benefits instead, to enter into a contract with the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust to repay those lump sums. In return for this repayment, the scheme recognises the actual period of prior parliamentary service towards future benefits, including pensions.

Currently, affected members may enter contracts with the trust within three months of re-entering parliament, with the trust having discretion to extend this period to six months. This bill will extend the period during which the trust has discretion to enter a contract from six to 12 months. In a number of past cases, and in one current one, this contract has not been signed within the six-month period. The extended discretionary period should allow the trust and any affected future members sufficient time to enter contracts.

The bill contains transitional provisions to allow current members who have not been able to enter repayment contracts with the trust to do so within three months of this bill receiving royal assent. The extended discretionary period is to be subject to a cut-off date in the event that the former member's parliamentary term expires before the end of any other period contained in the provisions. This is to ensure that the affected members' decisions are made while they are still members of the scheme.

The bill also proposes to replace the existing provision for repayment of the actual sum received with a repayment amount which is updated in line with movements in basic parliamentary salary from the time the original lump sum was paid until the time the affected member enters a contract with the trust. This would remove a possible windfall to the affected member, which arises from the current provisions, where he or she may have received interest on, or otherwise made use of, the lump sum amount. The level of basic parliamentary salary, applying from time to time, is used to calculate pension benefits and is therefore an appropriate index to be applied.

The bill contains a minor amendment to the Superannuation Laws Amendment Act 1994 to remedy a numbering error. In the context of the whole parliamentary contributory superannuation scheme, these amendments will have negligible financial impact. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be mercifully brief. The coalition supports these amendments. We have no difficulty with the amendments put forward by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott). He has explained the details of the proposal at some length. The important thing is that the proposed amendments do not in any way alter the basic design of the existing parliamentary superannuation scheme. Any financial impact is therefore negligible. If anything, it is probably a saving in that people who have previously served, have then

SPEECH.PARA: left parliament, and subsequently returned, will now be required to make up the difference in their lump sums, plus the effect of CPI adjustments and so forth which had previously not been the case. Consequently, any potential windfall under the old arrangements will be removed under the new arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow, 10 February, is the 31st anniversary of a national tragedy. I refer, of course, to the collision of the destroyer HMAS Voyager and the aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne off Jervis Bay with the loss of 83 lives. For six years in this place and elsewhere I have been fighting for the compensation cause of all those survivors—through this place, through the parliament generally, and also through the successful case before the Full Bench of the High Court of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Things became bogged down until, in May 1993, the now Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) gave us a glimmer of light and indicated that the compensation claims for those survivors would be resolved and would be resolved quickly. Unfortunately, as a result of further questions to the Attorney-General in June last year, it was clear that there were further sticking points to that compensation, caused in large part by some provisions of the government's Comcare legislation.

This evening I would like to reveal to the House the details of this in a letter that has been written to the Chairman of the Victorian Bar Counsel by James Taylor, a barrister who has been acting on behalf 70 or 80 of the survivors over a long period of time. It reads in part:

SPEECH.PARA: This letter is by way of a complaint against Mr. John McCarthy Q.C. and Mr. B. Knox and Mr J. Lenczner, all members of the Victorian Bar for an alleged breach of clause 5.12 Chapter 5 of the Victorian Bar Rules . . .

I act on behalf of Mr. Hugh Gilvarry who commenced proceedings in the Victorian Supreme Court by Writ No. 4937 of 1994. Mr. Gilvarry suffered psychological and physical injuries as a consequence of being a crew member on HMAS Voyager when it collided with HMAS Melbourne on the 10th February, 1964 on the high seas.
Mr Gilvarry's case is the vanguard for at least 70 survivors of the collision who have lodged claims by Writ.

Because these remaining survivors failed to issue Writs prior to the 1st December, 1988 they now are confronted with a Defence pleaded by the Commonwealth involving s.44 of the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (Commonwealth) commonly known as the ComCare Act, s.44 purports to take away Commonwealth employees right to bring an action for damages at Common Law for Writs issued after the 1st December, 1988.
He goes on to say:

The High Court decided that a cause of action is properly within the meaning of s.51(xxxi) and which was acquired by the Commonwealth NOT on just terms and therefore s.44 in those circumstances is unconstitutional.
It goes on:

. . . the Australian Constitution invalidates s.44 of the ComCare Act so far as it relates to actions where time has expired under the Limitation of Actions Act, i.e. can an action brought after the expiration of 6 years from the date upon the action arose have, value, or, benefit or `property'.
He finishes by saying:

Gilvarry's case was heard by His Honour Mr. Justice Nathan between 24th October, 1994 to the 28th October, 1994 decision being reserved by His Honour on that date. No mention was made by Counsel for the Commonwealth to His Honour that a relevant decision was reserved. The decision of Mewett was handed down by the Federal Court on 1st November, 1994. The parties went before His Honour Mr. Justice Nathan on the 15th November, 1994. No mention was made by Counsel for the Commonwealth to His Honour on that date. Despite the Commonwealth having had that decision for two weeks. Counsel for the Commonwealth did not inform His Honour of that decision between the 1st November, 1994 and the 15th November, 1994 when Gilvarry was reserved.
Counsel for the Commonwealth's actions seem to be in contravention of clause 5.12 of the Victorian Bar Rules.

There has subsequently been an interim reply from the Bar Council to that letter and, as I understand it, the Bar Council is looking at the issue. The reason I raise this matter this evening is that I have placed on the Notice Paper question No. 1976 which, in part, sets out the details and a number of questions for the Attorney-General. I simply say to the Attorney-General yet again: when are these cases going to be resolved? We know that $30 million to $50 million is involved in these compensation cases. It is in the national interest and in the interest of the individuals concerned to quickly have those issues resolved financially.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put on the record in this place my delight in seeing the Port Adelaide Football Club obtain the second licence in South Australia—
—The mighty Magpies!

—Yes, the mighty Magpies will enter the AFL competition, hopefully in 1996. The decision by the South Australian National Football League to give Port Adelaide the nod was not a forgone conclusion, as many people in South Australia believed. Port Adelaide, by the proverbial country mile, presented the most comprehensive and complete submission to the Football League. Contrary to what some of the losers would have us believe, the decision was based entirely on merit. On that basis, Port Adelaide was leaps and bounds ahead of all the other pretenders. Port Adelaide Football Club, like the Port Adelaide area, is full of history and tradition. It is the common thread that links the locals together which has brought about the most successful Australian Rules football club in history.
—And the executive.

—That is correct. The Port Adelaide football club is the oldest established club in South Australia, playing its first game on 24 May 1870. Since that time, the club has won a record 33 premierships, being runner-up 34 times and third, 24 times. It was out of the finals only 12 times. It is unparalleled in the history of Australian Rules. Five premierships have come in the last seven years.

PARA.TAB: Port Adelaide has the largest supporter base and membership of any SANFL club. It is a leader in football administration, which is reflected in the continual strong financial position of the club. To me, the choice was obvious. Only Port Adelaide can provide the alternative supporter base to the Adelaide Crows. I can tell that most locals, including me, were a little relieved and excited when the decision was made. Now there is a fair degree of eagerness to meet the challenge now emerging.

It means a lot to Port Adelaide as it meant a lot to the sister city of Fremantle in Western Australia. Port Adelaide is a city like Fremantle; it is a port town with a potential for development while retaining its historical charm. Fremantle had the America's Cup in the 1980s as the spur needed to get things moving. I hope that this will do the same thing for Port Adelaide. With the MFP close by, Port Adelaide is overripe for development. Indications of interest are now coming in at a reasonable rate. Port Adelaide has an identity very much its own, an identity very separate from the other parts of Adelaide. Its people are fiercely loyal to each other, to the area and to their successful football team. It is somewhat akin to the legendary Collingwood Football club in its loyalties, with a supporter base spread right across Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Same colours.

—We will have different colours in the new league, but I think we will still call them the Magpies. It is said often that you can take a person out of Port Adelaide but you can never take Port Adelaide out of a person. Such is the loyalty to Port Adelaide that it is imbibed from generation to generation.

PARA.TAB: Local people know the AFL decision will be good for business and employment in the area, bringing with it greater confidence in the future. This decision will definitely put Port Adelaide on the map with more visitors to South Australia likely to visit historic Port Adelaide. Port Adelaide is and always has been very much a working class community and this is strongly reflected in the membership of the football club. The club has a heart and a soul. The strength of the club is in its grassroots membership, not simply in corporate sponsorship, though that is of course important.

I would like to publicly add my congratulations and thanks on behalf of all Port Adelaide supporters to all of those people closely associated with Port Adelaide for its AFL bid. It would not have been possible without the tireless efforts of many people within the club. People such as club president, Greg Boulton; club chairman, Barry Wilson, former wharfie; football director, Jim Nitschke; and coach, Jack Cahill all deserve a mention, as well as the committee, players—past and present—and supporters.

Port Adelaide's CEO, Brian Cunningham, deserves a special mention. Brian, like most local lads, aspired to play for Port Adelaide from a very early age. He achieved that goal, went on to have a very distinguished playing career with Port Adelaide with many appearances for his state over that time and the reward of the club captaincy for his loyalty and leadership.

Brian returned to the club as chief executive officer in 1992 and has proven himself as a leader in football administration at a national level. I think I can sum it up with the motto of the club—`Proud of the past, confident of the future'. One thing is for sure, when we do actually enter the national competition, I would not miss it for quids. We have a trial match coming up in a couple of weeks against the Fremantle Dockers and I really do look forward to the day next year when Port Adelaide plays the Crows and Port Adelaide will definitely win.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party's resident Gordon Gekko, the bloke who makes Adam Smith look like a Keynesian, otherwise known as the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), was at it again this week exorcising the ghosts of the true believers from the ALP and giving us a grade three version of Labor history.

PARA.TAB: With a thimble of knowledge and only bravado camouflaging his foolishness, he chose to stick those bovver boots into the former anti-conscriptionist, Frank Anstey who, for all his failings, was a much respected Victorian Labor politician. I can see it now. There would be the member for Werriwa in the jacuzzi reading his economic textbook. He would come to the 1930s Depression and see Frank Anstey, socialist heretic, wanting to take the mickey out of the banks. The member for Werriwa would have jumped to his feet, stuck his nose in the air and said, `How old fashioned.'

The honourable member blithely and pompously mocks the past, oblivious to the fact that modest, thoughtful people accept that everyone is historically and circumstantially fashioned. This is exactly what E.P. Thompson meant when he said he wrote the book entitled The Making of the British Working Class to rescue working people from the enormous condescension of posterity. One could only assume E.P. Thompson, that renowned British Labour historian, had the likes of the member for Werriwa in mind when he penned those words.

If the member wants to condemn Frank Anstey for not being a flashy dressed 1990s bloke and for having some ideas particular to his times, then he should follow his line of argument through to its logical conclusion. If he did, he would be standing up in this place condemning the Prime Minister for opposing a motion to decriminalise homosexuality 22 years ago.

The old Prime Minister, who was not too old then, was not particularly radical when he lined up with Bob Katter Sr and some—dare I say it—right wing fogies to oppose the motion. Does the member for Werriwa have the intellectual courage to jump to his feet and tell us that the Prime Minister was either homophobic or ignorant of the predicament of homosexuals when he, the Prime Minister, opposed that motion? Or was it that there was a bit of the old B.A. Santamaria morality in P.J. Keating? I bet the honourable member did not have the courage to raise the issue over a snag at the Lodge last night. I bet he did not sidle up to the PM and say, `Listen, you old fogy, I'm not very happy about your attitude to homosexuality and what you said about women in your first speech.' No, I bet he did not.

The member for Werriwa crudely asserts that anyone who explores the ways in which unbridled globalisation can diminish cultural and national sovereignty is old fashioned or narrow-minded. This is patently anti-intellectual.

His is a doctrinaire view, blind to the cultural and economic foundations that an independent republican Australia should be built on. Contrary to the member's rhetoric and attempted point scoring, the coalition is just as committed to globalisation as the Labor Party. Anglophiles such as the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) will continue to wave the Union Jack, but ownership of Australia concerns them no more than it concerns the member for Werriwa.

It is interesting to hear the member dismiss Frank Anstey as an old-fashioned socialist. Would he have praised him if he had been a branch stacking, right wing bovver boy like Steve Conroy, the New South Wales Right's nomination for the Victorian Senate, or if he had been an opportunist careerist like Kelvin Thomson, the state ALP defector and now candidate for Wills? Had he been around in the 1930s, the member for Werriwa would have been there waving a grade 3 economics textbook as that great British banker Otto Niemeyer passed by to remind the Australian government that all loans had to be repaid. You see, in the lexicon of the member for Werriwa, the market rules, okay. That is why he drools over the Hilmer report.

Belatedly, it has now dawned on some Labor backbenchers that the Hilmer report might be used by the Kennett government to support its privatisation fetish. Hence the dorothy dixer to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) today. The problem was that all the minister said was that the government was opposed to monopoly ownership, not privatisation. So don't be surprised if the member for Werriwa is told to pull up on Hilmer until the party gets its story right.

I will bet the honourable member did not tell ALP members in his FEA just how little regard he had for Labor history and the true believers when he begged for pre-selection. Then again, there is every possibility he was foisted on the community via branch stacking. Conroy was happy to tell readers of the Melbourne Age that he had nothing but contempt for the Labor Left.

What distinguishes Latham, Conroy and Kelvin Thomson from the true believers of the 30s? Frank Anstey, Frank Brennan and John Curtin all had moral courage. They believed in an egalitarian future for Australia and subscribed to the view that government had a role to play in bringing about social justice and equitable economic outcomes.

In the 1990s, the likes of Frank Anstey would have had the courage to point out that an information superhighway was only as good as the quality of the ideas on it. In the middle of one banking crisis during the Depression, Frank Anstey referred to his cabinet colleagues as `only the stuffed effigy of a government'. Sounds like a bloke with a bit of spirit. Anstey, unlike the member for Werriwa, was neither a servant to vested economic interests nor a class traitor. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw the attention of the House to a concern that is presently held in the community by Hepatitis C sufferers. There is, I believe, a sense of frustration. In a letter I am about to read into Hansard, given to me by a constituent who gave his permission for such a letter to be incorporated in Hansard, there is a plaintive cry for help coming through from many such sufferers. His letter begins:

SPEECH.PARA: I am a Hep C positive and live in Orange, country NSW.
The story of how I came to learn that I had Hep C is an indication of the ignorance and critical shortage of services there is in country NSW for people with Hep C.

The following story is not an isolated example of misfortune. Discussions at our monthly Hep C support group meetings, a group which my wife and I started, has proven to me the ignorance of doctors and the apparent disinterest in treating Hep C patients, even in a regional centre like Orange with a population of more than 32,000 people, is more widespread than I had even feared it was. The problem is worse in the smaller satellite country towns which surround Orange.

Despite seeing a general practitioner (GP) for a year complaining about being tired and run down he could not tell me what was wrong with me. However after my wife say a television program (Ray Martin's midday show) which outlined the symptoms and causes of Hep C, I decided to change GPs. After examining me, my doctor said it looked like I had Hep C. So he sent me away for a blood test. The results came back a week later and they were positive.

Totally ignorant of what it meant to have Hep C I was then sent off to a local gastroenterologist. I did not know what to expect or what a gastroenterologist did. I only saw him once was then referred to the `interferon unit' at Westmead Hospital, in Sydney. This took six months and I had to wait a further six months for a liver biopsy to see how far gone, or the level of damage the Hep C virus had caused in me.

Needless to say this was an extremely traumatic time for me. However I was at no stage during this harrowing time ever given any support or counselling of any kind from anyone. I was constantly wondering what my prognosis was; death, cancer, or what?

Finally I was put onto a trial of interferon for a period of 12 months, but I suffered quite severe side-effects throughout this trial period (I was given a packet of injections whereby I'd inject the interferon in my stomach over two months). And again, I did not receive any counselling, or emotional support.

The worst part of the side-effects was the chemically induced depression. I kept complaining about it to my GP and to the registrars at Westmead. But my plight was ignored. I attempted suicide, but fortunately was not successful because I kept thinking of my five children, my wife and my faith in God.

Somehow, I don't know, I survived this traumatic, life-threatening time on interferon. After all of this I was told that the interferon had been unsuccessful. I went into shock on hearing this depressing news and had a car accident on the way home as I was still coming to terms with the fact that I was still Hep C positive.
Once again there were no social workers, or anyone, to help me.

I have been to the interferon clinic at Westmead every second month and have been promised more treatment each visit. I have been fed this line for the last 18 months. They say the reason is they do not have enough funding from the Federal Government but are hopeful of some money soon.

Then I was told I was ineligible for the program because I have already failed a trial period on interferon. I have been offered a four year trial on interferon. But going on the side-effects from the last trial I don't think I would be able to survive such a long-term trial. I am supposed to start this in February, 1995.
Living with the virus is bad enough. But living in a society that is ignorant of the virus and are uninformed about it and how it is transmitted is a living hell.
I had an encounter with a man in town that would not let me get any closer than a car distance from him because he thought he would be infected.

When I was first diagnosed with Hep C it was the most frightening time of my life. I did not know how I got it, if it could be caught by my wife, if it was sexually transmitted, or whether it had been passed on to our children. However, I am pleased to say, my wife and children are all negative.
He then points out some of the further suffering caused. In his final paragraph, he says:

When you consider there are 10,000 new cases of Hep C diagnosed each year compared with 800 HIV, stalling things will only compound the problem. If something is not done now, in 10 years we will have to spend all available medical funding on building liver transplant units all over the country to cope with the problem with Hep C. But, I bet, even then we won't spend the money!

In order to facilitate community awareness about the difficulties of Hep C sufferers, this support group in Orange will be conducting an information day next Monday, 13 February. I will be pleased to be associated with that day. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has a very poor record of remembering the contributions of its former political leaders and statesmen. We preserve very few of the relics that are associated with our former leaders. The first member for Wide Bay was Andrew Fisher, who also served three terms as Prime Minister. He was the first Australian Prime Minister to have a majority government and the first to be head of a Labor government—not the first Labor Prime Minister, but the first to be head of a Labor government. He is obviously closely associated with my electorate. Little has been done in this country to preserve the memory of this man and his contribution to Australia.

PARA.TAB: There are two houses in the electorate, one in Gympie and one in Howard, which are associated with Andrew Fisher—and both need attention. Andrew Fisher House in Gympie is currently owned by the historical society and was moved into its museum complex in 1973. The house has been fully restored and furnished in the style of the 1900s. It is closely associated with Andrew Fisher, the miner and engine driver from Gympie who rose from humble beginnings to become the Labor Prime Minister of Australia.

The house contains some of Andrew Fisher's personal belongings and has been listed by the National Trust of Queensland. The house urgently needs a new roof, and the society has asked the government on many occasions for financial assistance to help preserve this house. It has got very little support from members opposite, even though Andrew Fisher was a Labor Prime Minister. Only the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has given this cause much support. He has been to Gympie personally, has seen the house and has made applications to government ministers on a number of occasions for funding for this important project. Ironically, the minister at the table, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), is amongst those who have signed letters refusing financial assistance to restore Andrew Fisher House.

A second house has perhaps even greater association with this former Prime Minister. It was built and owned by Andrew Fisher in the town of Howard when he was a coalminer on the Burrum coalfields. I have a copy of the certificate of title which recognises Andrew Fisher as its owner.The house is in its original condition, although it has been unsympathetically added to over the years. It has had a number of owners subsequent to Andrew Fisher, with the current owners having it since 1972. They need money for an entry contribution to an aged people's complex, so the house is for sale.

This is a rare opportunity for a building that has a particular association with Australia's history—being owned by one of our great former prime ministers—to be acquired for national ownership. I appeal particularly to members opposite but also to the government as a whole to take up the opportunity of acquiring the house as a national museum and as something to remember one of our former prime ministers by. The house is clearly in need of some work to restore it to its original state, but it would be a very fitting monument to Andrew Fisher.

After Andrew Fisher retired as Prime Minister of Australia, he became high commissioner for Australia in London and he eventually died in England, where he is buried. I understand that his grave is largely unattended. There is very little by which to remember this great Australian Prime Minister. This is a unique opportunity—one which will possibly not come again. We need to move very quickly to acquire this building. I encourage government members, who have an association with the ALP, who would like to remember one of their former heroes, to take this opportunity to ensure that this building is not lost, that it is preserved and kept for future generations to remember one of the early Australian prime ministers—the first Prime Minister of a Labor government and someone who did so much to contribute towards the early history of our country.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: State Bank of New South Wales

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed by the utter gall of the previous speaker, the member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), by the shamefaced way in which he stood and spoke in this House. He was one of the people who was responsible for the garrotte being put on the program which would have funded exactly what he is now pleading for. It is utterly shameful for this man to now come before us and plead for such a program when he, with some help, knocked out a minister who had nothing to hide. It was an act of political `fatherlessness of a child'—I am trying to be parliamentary in the use of my language. This man comes in here and has the hide, the temerity, to start talking about how we should honour our fallen when he was directly responsible, along with another member, for this program going down. It is to his utter shame and to the utter shame of everyone in his electorate that he should be held contemptuously responsible for that. However, I will not waste my time on such riffraff.

PARA.TAB: The real reason I wish to speak is that I have a letter from Premier John Fahey. I am supposed to be pleased, as a State Bank customer in New South Wales, at receiving this letter which, to protect my privacy, was addressed and distributed by the State Bank on behalf of the New South Wales government. The New South Wales government is using a government instrumentality to peddle this propaganda.

I am glad that the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) is not here so he cannot correct any minor errors in terms of historical facts and dates; I will leave those out. The government savings bank operated and opened by Jack Lang for the benefit of people of New South Wales—which sadly went broke under some difficulties and became the Rural Bank of New South Wales—had a particular reference. I note the smiles on the faces of those opposite. One of the references of the Rural Bank of New South Wales is pertinent to the state of Australia at the moment. That reference was to make sure that the rural industries and agricultural people in this country had equal access to and equity in financial services. Somewhere, you have lost that. Somewhere in New South Wales it has been determined that that should be sold out. That is why those opposite have gone so quiet—because they know that their mate in New South Wales has sold out those principles.

Frank Anstey was mentioned in a previous speech. You have criticised the respect of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for Jack Lang, another one of our great men. You stand here and try to pull our great people up for your own cause. That is very hard to take. This letter from John Fahey states that the government guarantee over my deposits will be there for three years. What is he in fact saying? He is saying that the company to which they have sold this bank has been given government guarantees for three years. I suggest that that is a commercial thing. It has nothing to do with my interests, but has everything to do with ensuring that the company it has sold has been sold with a gold stamp of approval.

The second part of the letter relates to strength and competitiveness. It is almost a joke to suggest that the sale of this bank does anything for strength and competitiveness. I was one of those Australians who liked to put my savings in a government bank. I have to go back to the Commonwealth Bank, which is only 49 per cent owned by the people of Australia. But I will do that, not because I want to but because I have to. I do not have the choice. There is no competition. I do not have the choice to put my savings in a bank which is owned by the people of New South Wales. To suggest that this is going to strengthen the competitiveness is hoo-ha.

The last part of the letter relates to the prudent manner in which Reserve Bank supervision can be expected. Reserve Bank supervision has nothing to do with John Fahey. What is he on about? I suggest that John Fahey stop selling out the people of New South Wales. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott). He is a member of the party that started to sell the Commonwealth Bank—the great bastion of the Australian Labor Party, for the protection of the poor battler and the poor saver. He has been part of that sale process, and the government is going to sell the lot of it. The member had a bit of a chip at the state government. One cannot believe members like that. We should dismiss what they say and just take it as pure political rhetoric for the New South Wales election that is coming up.

PARA.TAB: Some weeks ago I made a speech in regard to the NRMA. I praised the directors for their decision to go ahead with the demutualisation. I also praised them for their stand against some of the crazier ideas that were being foisted on the NRMA and the motorists of New South Wales by an unusual conglomeration of people who wanted to do quite unusual things with shareholders' funds.

Since I made that speech, I have had a chance to examine some of the activities in the management of the NRMA, and I do not know whether I should have been as strong in my praise of the majority of board members. Some things have concerned me. The process that has been gone through is beneficial to motorists. I think that the loss of capital, which has reduced the average share value from $1,000 to $500, indicates that perhaps the expectations of the current board were too high in light of the circumstances. I look forward to the settlement of this process and I trust that the motorists of New South Wales will be able to make a reasonable decision when the new prospectus is issued.

I have to agree with the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) during that debate in relation to the role of Ms Lynn Ralph, who is the Deputy Chairperson of the Australian Securities Commission. Ms Ralph seemed to hold a very unusual dual capacity in this whole process. I believe that all public servants and servants of great institutions should be at arms length from commercial decisions. It was a commercial decision to sell, even though it is a mutual group. Ms Ralph's advice would have been seen to be more credible if she had stood back from her attachment to the NRMA or appointed somebody else to fill the role she undertook. I know that the motorists of New South Wales will be watching very carefully over the next few weeks as they decide whether or not that great organisation should be demutualised. I think I will be voting no.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 8 December 1994.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is to make amendments to legislation under the portfolio and to repeal obsolete legislation. The bill makes amendments to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 to add one member to the authority to represent the interests of Aboriginal people living adjacent to the park. While research indicates that no Aboriginal people live in the marine park, there are 13 Aboriginal communities located mainly along the northern part of the coast with an estimated population of 6,500 in addition to those residing in towns along the coast.

PARA.TAB: Hunting, fishing and gathering of marine animals for subsistence purposes are major activities in inshore waters adjacent to Aboriginal communities and areas, including towns, where Aboriginal people reside. In the light of the Mabo decision and subsequent legislation dealing with native title, the special provision for this representation on the authority of Aboriginal interests is warranted.

The bill also makes provision for doubling most of the penalties provided under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act, the incorporation of a mental fault element in accordance with the Commonwealth's criminal law policy, and a change from indictable offences to summary offences for many of the provisions. Penalties under that act have not been considered generally by the Parliament since 1988. Significant increases in use, demand and competition for resources have occurred since that time. Illegal activities in the marine park not only may reap substantial commercial benefits for the participants but also give rise to enormous and possibly irreversible impacts on the marine park.

Given the World Heritage status of the Great Barrier Reef, it is important that Parliament sends a clear message to potential offenders and the courts, indicating that it views such environmental offences as very serious. The waste discharge penalties for the owners and controllers of facilities within the marine park have been increased from 500 penalty units to 2,000. This is in line with other marine pollution legislation which attempts, through the imposition of higher penalties, to deter persons from committing offences that might lead to serious impacts, such as those that arose in the case of the Exxon Valdez.

The bill makes provision for the preparation of statutory management plans for parts of the marine park and for species and ecological communities within the marine park where such management plans are necessary. Given the dramatic increase in the use of the marine park in the last 10 years, it has now become obvious that the existing permits system is a poor tool for planning purposes, although it will continue to remain an excellent tool for general management purposes. Statutory management plans are therefore necessary to bridge the gap between zoning plans and individual permit decisions.

The bill increases the powers of marine park inspectors to improve the safety and efficiency of enforcement within the park. The marine park covers an area greater than Victoria and Tasmania combined, and is the largest marine protected area in the world. It is most important that the inspectors have adequate powers to enforce the Marine Park Act in areas which may be quite remote. Much of the park is not covered by mobile phone access and only a small area is covered by good quality seaphone.

The proposed amendments give inspectors the power to give reasonable directions to persons within the marine park for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the act. The bill also brings the provisions of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act relating to arrest and search of arrested persons in line with the Commonwealth policy on the exercise of those powers. Changes are also proposed to the regulation making powers to allow for infringement notices to be given for minor offences in the regulations and to remove gender specific language from the Great Barrier Marine Park Act.

The bill makes minor amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 to allow fees collected under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 for permits, authorities and applications to be paid into the Australian national parks and wildlife fund. This implements a recommendation that such fees be retained by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service made in the 1992 review of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. The amendment also clarifies and groups together moneys that can be paid directly into the Australian national parks and wildlife fund and moneys that must first be paid into the consolidated revenue fund for appropriation to the Australian national parks and wildlife fund.

Amendments are made to establishing legislation which allows four statutory authorities under the portfolio, namely the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian Sports Commission, the Australian Sports Drug Agency and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, the use of credit cards. This is to facilitate administration ease in day-to-day operations so that a good or service may be acquired by the agency using a credit card.
At the request of the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly, minor amendments have been made in the bill to the Norfolk Island Act 1979 to change the titles of the presiding officers in the assembly.

The Australian Sports Commission Act 1985 currently provides for a board comprising a chairperson, a deputy chairperson and up to 10 other members. It has always been the government's intention that these positions be filled by people with experience or expertise in sport, either as participants or as administrators. Recent changes to departmental administrative arrangements will see the Australian Sports Commission taking responsibility for additional sports related activities such as grants to lifesaving organisations. With reduced involvement of the department in sport issues and to ensure that adequate links are in place between the department and the Australian Sports Commission, it is proposed to have the departmental secretary hold an ex officio position on the commission's board. The proposed amendment to the act will enable that arrangement to be implemented without disrupting the operation of the existing board.

The proposed amendments will not have any significant financial impact, though some increase in revenue could result from the increased penalties for breaches of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the Environment, Sports and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, I state that the opposition has no particular problems with the amendments herein, but I would like to make comments on several of them. The first of those is that there is introduction in this bill of the mental fault element into certain offences and there is the intention to change from indictable to summary offences.

PARA.TAB: I must say we gave considerable thought to this matter, but I have to say that, with the delicacy of the marine park that we are talking about, it seemed to us that we should agree with the sentiment in the bill and that, even though people had not intended to do damage, they should have given reasonable thought to their actions before going about whatever activities they might be involved in. That applies to those people who are in charge of multi-tonnage vessels as well as it might apply to scuba divers and other people. Whilst I have to say some of us were critical of this change of liability, if you like, from intent to negligence, we felt that it was too important to leave as it was.

That leads us to the second major change in this area, which is the change from penalties to penalty units. As I understand it, those penalties have not been changed for a long time, and some of them obviously were out of date in regard to the sorts of fines that people should pay, and we thought that that was a useful change. So, although there was some discussion on the matter of mental fault, in the end we came down in favour of the changes made.

We noticed that there is also expansion of the powers to frisk-search and we agreed that people should be able to protect themselves as well as other people by expanding those powers. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Snowdon) has covered the other major parts of the bill.

The bill allows for the making of statutory management plans for areas, species and ecological communities within the park. We welcome that, although all of this is taking rather a long time, is it not? Management plans are a very vexed issue which we have raised in this chamber before. For example, there is no management plan for the Willandra Lakes park as yet. There is a draft plan, but 15 years on we are now in the process of drafting a plan for an area called the Willandra Lakes. That was nominated over 14 years ago as a heritage site, and we have just received a draft.

Progressively—and I have no doubt that this is true now—there has been some devaluation of the assets of those people whose properties, 19 of them, reside in the park. I think that one of the principles we have to establish in this matter of World Heritage and heritage in general is that if there is a wish to change the value by some action of the sovereign power or take some action which may change the value of people's assets, that has to be taken into account when the changes are made. One cannot simply go about the business, in the interests of the community, of making certain proclamations which take away one of the essential ingredients in democracy—or reduce the value of one of the essential ingredients in democracy—which is private property. As everybody knows, that is probably the main difference between our system in the West and the failed system, of which we have seen just the best examples in history, in eastern Europe. I reinforce the fact that these management plans have to be put in place.

That leads me to discuss—and this is the sort of place one should be able to have these discussions—the problem of the Lake Eyre listing. The Lake Eyre World Heritage listing was proposed by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the last election. It has got the Labor Party into terrible trouble because nearly everybody involved—and I have had probably hundreds of letters by now coming into my office—is against the listing of Lake Eyre. I do not think any of those letters is against the proposition of World Heritage listings per se, but they are complaining about the fact that somebody is going to impose a listing upon them without the full agreement of the local community.

Honourable members know as well as I do that the World Heritage listing requirements have been changed in recent times—back in 1993. They have been changed—and I have raised this view before—because Australia conducted an internal row all over the world with the World Heritage commissioners. The Australians involved rang them up, sat on their doorsteps and had Australia's Daintree row right there. Those commissioners told Australia very directly in 1973 to sort out our problems in our own little burg before we burdened them with them. What they have said is in regard to cultural listings, and we think that ought to apply to natural listings as well. They told us to get the full approval of the local community first; then they would have a look at any World Heritage possibility and evaluate it.

It is time for the government to come clean with this and all the other World Heritage listings. Not too many people take much notice of the Willandra Lakes one because not too many people know about it. I know 45,000 people go there every year but they do not go twice; they go only once. That is interesting but it is not like the Barrier Reef or wilderness areas of Tasmania; it is an interesting anthropological and archaeological site. There is plenty of land around there that looks exactly the same. I go over it quite often.

That raises another question concerning a desktop study—that is how it was originally described by the CSIRO—being done by two gentlemen who have been subcontracted for them. My guess is that this matter was decided by Simon Balderstone or somebody like that in the office of the Prime Minister, by somebody in the department of the environment or maybe by somebody in the office of Senator Faulkner, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. The two gentlemen, Julian Reid and Jim Puckridge, who are supposed to be evaluating and doing some of this study have already declared public positions. If the government continues to appoint people such as that, it will get into exactly the same problem it had in regard to the reassessment of the 85 coupes, the 1,300 coupes, the 509 coupes, the 511 coupes or the 66 coupes—whichever number it happens to be this week—that are going to come out this Friday.

What actually happened was that the government appointed to do that re-evaluation people from organisations whose positions were previously known. Of course, that does not cover the amazing circumstance where at least 10 of the coupes in Victoria do not exist and it does not make much comment about the fact that it appears that two of the coupes in Tasmania are somewhere out in the middle of Bass Strait with no navigational lights, as the ex-member for Denison pointed out in the Tasmanian parliament. They have no navigation lights; they are just floating around in the middle of Bass Strait. Of course, those sorts of problems occur if the evaluation is not done by people of absolutely independent scientific repute.

Talking on this particular bill in this reasonably uncontentious Main Committee gives me the opportunity to make a few remarks. The honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) raised the question of World Heritage. The government will never get the agreement of the local community because of the way it is going about getting Lake Eyre as a World Heritage listing. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and others in the government have so offended the local community that they will never get their agreement. I do not know how the government will ever get them to agree. Organisations are already working hard against the government. There would not be one person in the whole area, Aboriginal or anybody else, who seems to be supporting it.

That does not seem to me to be the way that we should be encouraging World Heritage listing of areas in Australia. We did it pretty well in the Barrier Reef; we did it pretty well in the Antarctic. We have just listed two sets of caves: one in Queensland and one in Naracoorte in South Australia. Nobody objected to that. It was done well. It will be an advantage to the people living in those two areas, to the people running tourist operations and to the governments concerned. But what has happened in Lake Eyre is that everybody is agin the government. How on earth can that be of benefit either to the—

TALK.START.PARA: —What's your point?

—The point is that the government had better smarten itself up and organise some of the people who are designing these programs, including the Prime Minister. The only reason listing is being pushed is that he pushed it at the last election and, of course, we could not possibly change anything that the Prime Minister said, could we?

PARA.TAB: I am raising two very important matters. Firstly, if a new listing is to be declared—either a natural or a cultural listing—there must be full approval from the local community. Secondly, a management plan has to be put in place straightaway. The listing requirements require a management plan to be put in place straightaway after the application has been made. I make these comments because I think these issues are important. I will not hold up the Main Committee any longer. We have no objections to the amendments in the bill and therefore we will let it go through without challenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, which amends legislation administered by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. It covers a range of issues which include the issues pertaining to the supervision and development of various procedures for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. It also involves management plans for ecological communities within the marine park and obviously a number of issues that go across what is a very complex portfolio.

PARA.TAB: My comments on the bill will relate to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, coastal zone protection and related conservation issues. Given that part of my electorate is actually in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park area and has a sizeable coastal area, I am very concerned about coastal protection. It is to the credit of this government that it has had a very positive record on environmental issues. It is unfortunate that once again we are shown by the opposition a very parochial perspective. The shadow spokesperson who preceded me, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), was commenting on Lake Eyre as if people in whose backyard it is are the only ones who have any concern about it. I do not believe that we can afford to handle issues of conservation and heritage and what we are going to leave to future generations from a parochial or states rights position.

It would be my contention that increasingly the Australian community looks to the federal government to take a leadership role on these conservation issues, because they are issues that ought not be in the province of local governments solely or, indeed, state governments solely. The sorts of resources that we are looking to protect and pass on not only to future generations of this country but as part of the natural resources of the world are an issue that we must think about nationally and on which we must cooperate at a international level for regional and even global protection. This is what this government has been about.

I refer to a speech that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) gave in Wollongong in September 1994, when he made reference to our involvement with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. He said that on 1 August 1994 Australia declared an exclusive economic zone covering 12 million square kilometres in area, one of the largest EEZs in the world, and that we will soon ratify the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. That convention and declaration are going to be hugely important to the economy of our country and to the protection of our natural resources, and came about only because this government made sure that it committed itself to its responsibility to negotiate in various international bodies, including the United Nations, to make sure that we protected not only our own area but our regional area. In the same speech the minister made mention of negotiations with regional groups in ASEAN and the Asia-Pacific area for regional protection initiatives. It is very important that we commit ourselves to this.

Often I hear the opposition, in various speeches in the Main Committee room and also in the main chamber, berating the government for its commitment to United Nations conventions and declarations, as if this in some way impinges on our sovereign rights. It is my view and, I am sure, the government's view that such conventions are enormously important not only to our sovereignty but also to our responsibilities to the wider, international scene. In his speech the minister reminded his listeners of a number of initiatives that this government has taken, yet there has been, in the most recent debate on the woodchip issue, an attempt by a number of people to suggest that this government's record on conservation issues leaves a lot to be desired.

The constitutional arrangements in this country—which I contend are an overlay of the colonial posturings that occurred some 100 years ago, when various vested interests were more concerned with maintaining their parochial rights than with the future good of the nation—have meant that the Commonwealth has been hamstrung in meeting its national responsibilities because many of the powers that it would require remain the responsibility of the states. So, on many of these issues—and the woodchipping issue is a good example—we cannot get agreement as a national government without the agreement of the state governments. That has created a great many difficulties.

In this legislation there is some attempt, particularly with coastal issues, to move in that direction. In relation to coastal management, it is important to remind ourselves that over 75 per cent of Australians live and work in coastal areas. Therefore, the protection of our coastal areas is very important. I refer to an article by Julian Cribb in the Australian of 1 July 1992. The article was about initiatives of the CSIRO and was titled, `The toxic cocktail that threatens our coast'. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: More than 4 million people live within 3km of the sea. By 2050, if the national maritime urge persisted, they would number at least 7 million, said Dr Doug Cocks, of the CSIRO Division of Wildlife and Ecology.

In that article, Dr Cocks is quoted as referring to eight development hot spots around the coast which face extreme threat. They include Cairns-Townsville, Brisbane-Gold Coast, Coffs Harbour-Port Macquarie, Newcastle-Sydney-Wollongong, the far south of New South Wales and Perth-Bunbury. At that time the CSIRO initiated a three-year coastal zone program, which was launched by Professor Adrienne Clarke. Professor Clarke is quoted in the article as saying:
The coastal zone suffers from a whole range of problems—from sewerage and chemical pollution to loss of crucial wildlife habitat and fish breeding grounds.
The article continues:

PARA.TAB: She said agriculture, cities and industry contributed a chemical cocktail of nutrients, pesticides, heavy metals and eroded soil to rivers, with a devastating effect on the coast—leaving waters unfit for swimming, fishing or drinking.
"These problems extend right around Australia, in rural and urban areas and on the land and sea," she said.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, not a great deal has changed since that time. It is vitally important, particularly for the marine environment which takes the run-off from our land use, that we are aware of protecting coastal areas. Areas such as mangroves and coastal estuaries are important breeding grounds for our fish. I mentioned this yesterday when I spoke on the Prawn Boat Levy Bill. It is good that our commercial fishing organisations are now concerned about these issues.

PARA.TAB: In relation to one of the government's excellent decisions last year on Shoalwater Bay in my electorate, the commercial fishermen's organisation was a key player, along with a wide array of other groups. What became very clear in the work that was done by local communities and the evidence that was put to the commission of inquiry, which was initiated by the federal government prior to the 1993 election, was that there was unanimity of support. This is an excellent case example of the way individuals and communities can make a difference.

In the May/June/July 1994 edition of Wilderness News, there is a report on the purchase by the state government of the Starcke land in Far North Queensland. That article quotes Margaret Mead, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Don't ever believe that a small group of committed citizens can't change the world, indeed, it is the only thing that ever has.
This quotation is very apt because there is a tendency to see representative groups—and, in this case, conservation groups—as presenting an extremist viewpoint.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, when the small group of people got together over Shoalwater Bay other people saw them as a group of greenies who were at the extreme end of the continuum who did not represent a broader community sentiment. Over a period of years their commitment and their effort brought that constituency to a very wide group of community interest groups. By the time I took the caucus environment committee to Shoalwater Bay to inspect it and to meet with those groups, the thing that most impressed it was the unanimity of concern from groups as diverse as the returned servicemen's organisations, the conservationist groups, the local government authorities and the army—a wide range of groups. That was reinforced by the polling results carried out for the commission of inquiry which indicated that a majority of people were concerned to protect Shoalwater Bay. One of the issues that was of great concern to it was the water quality of the Capricorn coast.

If we look at the issues that we have been debating in this House recently, particularly the woodchip decision, we all need to be very clear that, yes, there are particular and vested interest groups involved in the debate and there are conflicting agendas and requirements. There is a clear indication from national polling that the people of Australia are concerned about the quality of their environment and want the federal government to involve itself.

It is important to take note of the Resources Assessment Commission which, after an extensive inquiry into our coastline, recommended that the Commonwealth should take a greater role. It may well be that what we have to move to is a very positive, cooperative approach with the three levels of government. It is going to require much more effective cooperation from state governments, which have shown themselves to be entirely recalcitrant over many conservation and heritage issues, playing for political point scoring rather than moving forward to protect important areas for ecologically sustainable development and also making sure that we provide a large amount of wilderness and natural protection areas.

In its most recent report on the carrying capacity of this country, the Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies made the point once again and very clearly that, although we are a vast continent, most of our continent is not habitable and is not available for agricultural pursuits. We are talking about a relatively small part of our land mass. Australians have a perspective that, because we have so much room and a small population, we do not have to worry too much about our resources. This is a very misconceived position. Relatively speaking, we have to protect and conserve areas of important natural resources. We have to remember, for instance, that our forests not only are effectively the lungs of Australia but also contribute to the lungs of the world and to our water quality.

When we look at our coastal areas which abut the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park we remind ourselves that pollution from the coastline and from the interior is going to affect the Great Barrier Reef itself. Further to that, I quote from the Age of July 1992 from Greg Roberts when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The amount of detrimental nutrients and sediments flowing from the Queensland coast to the Great Barrier Reef is between four and five times what it was before European settlement.

PARA.TAB: According to a Queensland Government report to be released next month, 77,000 tonnes of nitrogen and 11,000 tonnes of phosphorus are washed annually from the state's catchments.

The report, `A Preliminary Assessment of Sediment and Nutrient Exports from Queensland's Coastal Catchments', and the first to quantify potential pollution levels in the reef, says 15 million tonnes of sediments are also washed annually from the catchments. Sediment kills coral by reducing sunlight in the water . . .
Scientists are unsure whether the growing incidence of bleaching worldwide may be due to natural causes such as unusually hot weather or to global warming caused by the greenhouse effect.

Dr Oliver said that last February between 10 and 20 per cent of coral in reefs around Magnetic Island, the Whitsundays and the Great Keppel group was found to be bleached. This was the fourth time bleaching had been noted on the reef since monitoring began in 1979.
"There is concern that it is an indicator of overall global change but we really don't know and it could be local anomalies," Dr Oliver said.

SPEECH.PARA: When we say we have only looked at it since 1979, what is clear is that since European settlement, human habitation has been changing the reef and what is a priceless resource to the world global environment.

PARA.TAB: We have a huge responsibility here so that, when farmers are fertilising areas with low natural nutrients, that fertiliser is moving into our river systems. That is a very important issue which we all have to participate in. It is really going to take a very effective initiative from all levels of government. I am concerned that, unless the Commonwealth takes the lead in this matter through existing or new legislation, we will continue to find ourselves in these negative positions where we spend days, weeks, months and years negotiating with states which are playing political games about these important issues.

I believe that the community at large looks to the Commonwealth. Unfortunately, and with the help of various media outlets, the community blames the Commonwealth for these issues without realising that our constitutional arrangements make it very difficult for us. However, I do see this current legislation as part of an important series of moves to protect our coastal areas. I encourage cabinet members in their deliberations on the Resource Assessment Commission report—

TALK.START.PARA: —Will they take any notice?

—They certainly will not take any notice of the honourable member for Fisher, and I would commend them for that. I would encourage the cabinet to take cognisance of some of the recommendations from the Resource Assessment Commission, particularly in coastal protection. I say that because there are major issues right round the country, particularly where you see development that has been the result of local governments allocating land that should never have been subdivided for housing development so close to foreshores. That land is now being affected by beach erosion and so on. To remedy the situation will cost a huge amount of money but it is an issue which is in the sovereign area of the states.

PARA.TAB: I commend this legislation to the House and I hope that this government will continue its excellent record on forging ahead on environmental issues and negotiating with community groups for the better welfare of our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would like to say that I was sorry to hear the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) say that the cabinet ought not to listen to what I say in relation to the environment and in relation to this bill. We really ought to appreciate that, as Australians, none of us has a monopoly of wisdom in the area of the environment. In fact, we need to protect the environment for future generations and when people, regardless of whatever political party they are from, come forward with a good idea, then it is vital in the nation's interest that that idea be taken on board.

PARA.TAB: However, this is what is known as an `omnibus' bill. That means that a large number of items of legislation are being altered as a result of this one bill, the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994.

I have spoken before in the committee about my concern over the way that the government seems to bring in a grab bag of disparate proposals and lump them all under the one amending bill. It makes it very difficult for people to follow the amendments through from the omnibus bill into the various pieces of principal legislation being altered as a result of the omnibus bill. It could be that that argument is long lost, as the government continues to bring omnibus bills before the parliament. I suppose the government might suggest that by doing this it reduces the amount of time spent on a bill, particularly as a number of the amendments being changed in an omnibus bill are not controversial. Perhaps this is deemed to be an efficient means of processing them through the parliament.

This Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill amends the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, the Norfolk Island Act 1979, the Australian Sports Commission Act 1989, the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 and the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990. I am very pleased to speak on this bill. As a person who has always lived his life in Queensland, either at or by the sea, I am very aware of how important the sea is and of how important proper environmental management of the sea is, not only to the future of tourism but also to the future of the environment and to the future of Australia generally.

We ought to appreciate that we hold our environment and our country in trust for future generations. I strongly believe that in the past environmental considerations were not adequately taken into account. I am pleased that both sides of politics are taking a greater interest in the environment, as indicated by the environmental statement released by the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) just a short time ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very important to realise that the Liberal Party is very concerned about the environment. The honourable member for Barker has made very many public statements and has an excellent record in relation to the environment. I must say that we on this side of the chamber get very annoyed and bridle at the government when it tries to suggest that it is indeed the fount of all wisdom on the environment. After 12 years of government, the environmental record of the Labor Party really does not stand up to scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: Although some people would suggest that this legislation is essentially cosmetic, there are a number of major changes. But, as was indicated by the honourable member for Barker, the coalition supports the broad thrust of these amendments. I suppose that if we did not support them the legislation would not be debated in this place. Underpinning our support for these amendments is our concern, and very strong backing, for the principle that an environmentally clean Australia will be a great boost to industry, to our tourism future, to our international reputation and to the quality of life for future generations of Australians. It is very easy for us to despoil and to not to take into account what we ought to preserve for future generations. It is always vital to have a balance and I hope that this legislation preserves that balance in favour of the environment because we need to make sure that the quality of life that we enjoy in Australia today is available for future Australians.

There are a number of amendments to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act. These amendments essentially add a member of the authority to represent the interests of Aboriginal people living adjacent to the park. They also increase many of the penalties under the act to ensure that they provide an effective deterrent, introduce the mental fault element into the relevant offences, change them from indictable to summary offences and revise the waste discharge provisions to make them consistent, as far as is appropriate, with the Marpol convention. The amendments also allow for the making of statutory management plans for areas, species and ecological communities within the marine park which provide for more efficient planning for use of the marine park while protecting and conserving the values of the marine park and providing for further public participation in planning and management processes of the marine park.

The amendments also seek to improve the safety and efficiency of the exercise of the powers of marine park inspectors by providing a power to give reasonable directions within the marine park to ensure compliance with the act; clarifying the arrest and search of arrested persons provisions so as to make them consistent with Commonwealth criminal law policy; introducing a penalty provision for failing to comply with the conditions of release of seized items; and introducing a deliver-up power and powers to seize weapons, take and make copies of documents which may provide evidence of an offence, order persons from only a part of the marine park, and exercise certain powers off the marine park when a police officer who is an inspector is not available.

There are also amendments relating to gender terminology; and amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Act, which enable fees collected under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 to be paid to the Australian national parks and wildlife fund, and also allow for the use of credit cards by the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. There are also amendments to the Australian Sports Commission Act, the Australian Heritage Commission Act and the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act, which allow for the use of credit cards by these agencies.

As I have said, it is an omnibus bill and it is interesting to notice that a number of acts have been amended by this bill. The coalition is not opposed to the inclusion of a member of the Aboriginal community on the barrier reef authority. One ought to appreciate that the basic function of the authority is to provide information, make recommendations, and advise the minister on matters associated with the care and management of the park. Until now, the membership of the authority has consisted of three people: a chairman and two others. I hope that the inclusion of an Aboriginal person is not tokenism. Aboriginals are really part of the Australian community and it is important that, as Australians, we appreciate that Aboriginals are Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said they weren't?

—No one has said that they are not, but the point is that the existing members of the authority represent all Australians, whether they be Aboriginals or whether they be people from other ethnic origins. I think that the government is guilty of tokenism by suggesting that it is necessary to include an Aboriginal person, when the interests of Aborigines, like the interests of other Australians of our diversity of ethnic cultures, would be properly represented by the people already on the authority. However, the coalition is certainly not opposing the inclusion of an Aboriginal person.

PARA.TAB: A number of the penalties are increased under the act, to ensure that they provide an effective deterrent. We may have some concerns over the alterations of the mental fault element to a lesser standard, in order to assist in prosecutions—but, on balance, the protection of the Great Barrier Reef is so important that we certainly do not oppose what the government is seeking to achieve here.

The Great Barrier Reef is one of the wonders of the world and all of us have a vested interest in its preservation. I have received a number of complaints from people who have been fishing up around the Great Barrier Reef. They have seen various ships meandering through the Great Barrier Reef in a way which suggests that those ships may be lost. There is the danger that, if the ship was not navigating correctly, it could have an oil spill, with devastating consequences to the environment in that area.

The amendment also revises the waste water discharge provisions, so as to bring Australia into line with the Marpol convention. Parties who are signatories to that particular convention have a responsibility to prohibit marine pollution violations and to take legal proceedings against offenders. The environmental consequences of an oil tanker running into a reef on the Great Barrier Reef and releasing an enormous amount of oil would be horrendous. Anyone would support amendments which seek to make sure that such a thing does not occur.

The bill also makes amendments to allow for the making of statutory management plans for areas, species and ecological communities within the park. Of course, that is positive. There ought to be community input into those plans so that the plan which is released and becomes binding does represent the collective will of the community. I understand that a draft plan has now been released but it took 14 years for this government to bring it forward.

When I look at my own electorate and, in particular, the Glasshouse Mountains area where the state government has promised a management plan to protect the environment and to regulate the use, the maintenance and the protection of those particular mountains, I am disgusted at the fact that the government has not come forward with a draft plan. We have a situation there where commercial tourism operators have actually been banned from the Glasshouse Mountains area. Ecotourism is a vital area of tourism in my electorate and a lot of those ecotourism operators at present are locked out of the Glasshouse Mountains because there is no management plan. The government says that it is going to prepare one but it has been too busy. I would like to take this opportunity to say that I certainly hope it does not take 14 years for a draft plan to be released for the Glasshouse Mountains in the same way this federal Labor government has taken 14 years to release a draft plan for the Great Barrier Reef.

With any plan, it is important that one has community input. When a draft plan is released, it should be open to public comment before the plan is set in concrete. The government stands condemned for being very slow in this area. I certainly hope that the state Labor government does not take 14 years. If it takes 14 years to bring down a management plan for the Glasshouse Mountains, a lot of jobs will be lost and the ecotourism industry will suffer greatly.

It ought to be noted that ecotourism is a very sensible and a very good form of tourism. I see the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) is nodding enthusiastically. People come into an area and these ecotourism operators actually teach them about the environment. They teach people about the species of flora and fauna in an area; they teach people how to take care of the environment. People leave the area not only having spent dollars and having created jobs, but also with a better understanding of our environment.

I would like to take this opportunity publicly to call again on the state Labor government to increase the priority of a management plan for the Glasshouse Mountains. It is simply unacceptable that the current situation where commercial tourism operators are locked out of the Glasshouse Mountains is allowed to continue.

We also support the amendment which does give additional rights to marine park inspectors to enable them to clarify the arrest and search of arrested persons. These amendments are consistent with the Commonwealth criminal law policy. Under the proposals, inspectors will be restricted to either an ordinary or a frisk search of an arrested person at or soon after arrest. It should be noted that a frisk search involves patting down the person where an ordinary search involves an inspection of items when removed—a coat or hat or articles in a person's possession.

The ability for inspectors to be able to perform a frisk search is consistent with the provisions on the search of an arrested person in other Commonwealth legislation, for example, the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994, with frisk searches consistent with customs matters. While the Liberal Party, being the guardian in this nation of individual liberty and freedom, does have concerns at times with the areas of personal privacy, on balance, I think it is important that the commission's inspectors be given this power. After all, it would be so easy to smuggle some items of flora and fauna off the reef.
