It is vital to make sure that people who are despoiling the reef are apprehended because, as I said before, we hold our environment, including the reef, in trust for further generations.

I notice the bill also deals with the removal of what is termed `gender specific' terminology. I think, to be honest, one ought to realise that English is a gender based language and the government has an obsession with supposedly non-sexist language. For instance, the word `chairman' has been considered by some to be sexist but the honourable member for Charlton, being a very erudite gentleman, would know that the word `chairman' is nothing to do with the masculine gender but comes from a Latin derivation—manus, meaning the hand. I suppose, however, that is an argument that has been long lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the same with `alderman'—all that nonsense about `alderperson' and so on. I agree with you.

—It is absolute nonsense, as the honourable member for Charlton says. The government really ought to take a realistic approach and perhaps not bring in some of these convoluted terms that always appear to be introduced into the legislation. In any event, the coalition is not going to go to the barricades on that particular issue in relation to this particular bill.

PARA.TAB: We do have some worries about allowing the use of credit cards by certain officers. I outlined earlier who will be permitted to use credit cards. One would only have to consider the Auditor-General's report No. 21 of 1993-94. There the Auditor-General—who has retired, much to the joy of the government, I suppose—was critical of the use of departmental credit cards. The government, instead of restricting their use sufficiently, is indeed encouraging their use.

I suppose there is the other side of the question there, too. If people do achieve such a senior Public Service position as some of these gentlemen who achieve that particular level—sorry, gentlepersons, if one wants to observe the spirit of the government's amendments—perhaps they ought to be given the responsibility of signing a credit card. Certainly one ought to watch that very closely, because there is a possibility of abuse and, indeed, such abuse has occurred in the past.

The coalition is very strongly supportive of Australia's environment. I must say that I am fairly disappointed with the proposal by the government to bring in a carbon tax because a carbon tax will not help the environment. In reality, it is simply a grab for money. If the government were to adopt the environmental program outlined by the coalition, which would ensure that there is enormous revegetation of Australia to replace a lot of the trees which have been cut down and to ensure that there is cessation of broadacre clearing, then we would be able to achieve a very much greater reduction in greenhouse gas emissions than will occur as a result of the government's carbon tax. One really ought to see the government's carbon tax for what it is: a grab for money, yet another tax increase, another broken promise. The government stands condemned for not coming clean and saying that it is desperately short of money. Of course, it is dressing up the carbon tax as an environmental levy.

The other thing that is of concern is the failure by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) in the Senate yesterday to reject the possibility that the government may well be planning to bring in a five per cent services tax on tourism, including ecotourism, which will affect the ecotourism operators operating in the area of the Great Barrier Reef. We really need to encourage people to come to the reef and encourage them to understand the environment there—the flora and the fauna—and to understand what a wonder of the world the Great Barrier Reef is. If the government is going to hike taxes—in effect, to add more taxes onto the backs of the tourism industry—then it is going to be more difficult for people to be able to afford to go there. If the cost of every charter boat is going to go up by five or 10 per cent, the cost of every bed is going to go up by five or 10 per cent and the cost of everything in that area is going to go up by five or 10 per cent, then fewer people are going to go there, or they will stay for a shorter time or they will not be able to afford to spend as much money. We really need to create jobs through ecotourism and other tourism operations.

As I said, we do not oppose this particular piece of legislation. It is a step in the right direction. We must condemn the government for its shocking environmental record over the last 12 years and we must, of course, condemn the government for its broken promises. It lied its way into winning the last election. The government stands condemned and the government, in my view, will be defeated at the next election overwhelmingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is an omnibus bill which contains various amendments to a number of different principal acts. The bill has no particular central theme and I have decided to concentrate my discussion on those aspects of the bill that are particularly relevant to my constituents—namely, those concerned with the operation of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

PARA.TAB: Recognition of the need to protect the reef obviously goes back to the times when Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people came to Australia; but in terms of legislative action it goes back to 1975, when the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was passed with bipartisan support. Formal international recognition of the reef's universal value came in 1981, when it was inscribed on the World Heritage list. With the listing of the wet tropics in 1988, my electorate of Leichhardt can lay claim to being one of the few places in the world where two World Heritage areas border one another. At Cape Tribulation—which I know you have visited, Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon—one can look to one's left to see the magnificent rainforest covered mountains of the wet tropics and then look out to sea and see the shadows of the Great Barrier Reef.

As I have said several times in the House, it is critical that we protect the reef from damage from oil spills. I know the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) mentioned that, and I certainly think we have got bipartisan support for this. One way that we are doing this is through the Great Barrier Reef strategic plan. The plan in itself is an achievement unique in the world; and quite rightly so, given the unique nature of the reef. It represents an ambitious and far-sighted effort to develop a long-term vision for the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area by formulating appropriate objectives and management strategies for ecologically sustainable development. Creating the plan involved a comprehensive consultative process in which more than 60 peak organisations and representative bodies from a wide cross-section of the community participated. An independent chairperson was employed to ensure that competing interests were considered and to facilitate the joint decision making process.

Another way we are acting to protect the reef is via legislation like the legislation we are dealing with today. The provisions in the bill for tougher penalties for breaching environmental controls will be welcomed by everyone in the far north. I think it is very fair to say that there has been wide community concern about inadequate penalties in the past. I have been the member for Leichhardt for the last two years, and I have seen a lot of people in the streets and in my office who are concerned about the Great Barrier Reef, and who are concerned that we do the right thing by the Great Barrier Reef. There is concern that there has not been enough enforcement in the past.

People in Far North Queensland recognise not only that we have to preserve the Great Barrier Reef for obvious ecological reasons, for passing something on to future generations, but also that it is a vital part of tourism in Cairns. People talk about ecotourism. It is a buzz word at the moment, and I think that people do not understand ecotourism as a particular niche market of tourism. Generally, in Cairns, it does not matter whether it is ecotourism or other sorts of tourism. People come to Cairns and they go to the reef and go to see the other natural attractions like the wet tropics area. Some of that is not ecotourism. Some people do not particularly want to go into depth about the Great Barrier Reef, they just want to see the beauty of it. I think that is fine in itself, and that is what we have got to recognise. The people, the tourism industry and business in Cairns recognise that as well, so these amendments will get widespread support.

I want to go back to oil spills. In 1991 the Commonwealth made it compulsory for large vessels, particularly those carrying oil and environmentally hazardous chemicals, to carry a pilot while navigating the northern section of the reef. No other country in the world has been able to obtain international acceptance of the need for foreign ships to carry pilots in international waters. This acceptance indicates the international recognition of the need to protect this natural wonder.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park does not cover the Torres Strait, I am going to make a few comments about the Torres Strait in my speech today, because the Great Barrier Reef itself goes into the Torres Strait. I must say—and I have said this publicly—that I think we have got to very seriously look to have compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait as well. If we do not do that then we are taking the risk of an oil spillage in the Torres Strait. Think of the devastation both to the natural environment and to the indigenous people in the Torres Strait, who depend on the sea to provide a great bulk of their food. Certainly the food that was spoken about—dugong, turtle, fish and cray—is the most nutritious part of their food, so if there was an oil spill which led to widespread devastation of the environment in the Torres Strait then it would literally impoverish people in the Torres Strait. It would be a situation of national crisis, so we do have to look seriously at compulsory pilotage there.

The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Ships of Shame: Inquiry into Ship Safety noted that the international maritime industry has accepted this general requirement. I have already referred to the requirement for pilotage in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, and the situation is recognised worldwide. The Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 contains a minor amendment to clarify the penalty provisions for operating a regulated ship without a pilot.

Mention has been made of the International Convention of 1993 for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships. The International Convention was subsequently amended by protocol in 1978. The convention is now commonly referred to as Marpol 73/78, and addresses the issue of ship-generated pollution. Marpol 73/78 contains five separate annexes which are implemented on a progressive basis by signatories to the convention. The type of ship-generated pollution covered by the annexes is broad: annex I covers oil; annex II covers noxious liquid substances; annex III covers harmful substances in packaged form; annex IV covers sewage, but it should be noted that this annex is not yet in force; and annex V covers garbage. The annexes cover everything that could threaten the natural environment of the sea. It can be seen that it is not only oil we are dealing with, but also many other things.

In the area of oil pollution from ships, Marpol 73/78 has regulations which extend the application of certain parts of the convention to ships which have cargo spaces constructed and utilised for carrying bulk oil of an aggregate capacity of 200 cubic metres or more. Marpol 73/78, regulation 2.2, expands the definition of `oil tanker' to include smaller cargo vessels which, although not conventional oil tankers, are capable of spilling significant quantities of oil.The expanded definition will also apply to, say, large coal carriers, which navigate the reef waters and which can contain up to 10,000 tonnes of fuel oil.

The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) chaired the Ships of Shame inquiry. The honourable member emphasises—and I believe that he is right—that it is not the oil tankers that are the greatest risk; it is the smaller ships, or, to use the colloquial term, the `rust buckets'. Although it will probably not be a modern oil tanker that will run aground but one of these smaller ships, nevertheless, considerable damage could be caused.

One of the proposed amendments in the bill, item 1 in schedule 1, adopts the Marpol 73/78 expanded definition of an oil tanker so that the protective measures for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park extend to this type of vessel and are consistent with Marpol 73/78. Parties which are signatories to Marpol 73/78 are obliged to prohibit marine pollution violations and to take legal proceedings against offenders. Article 4 of the convention is the relevant article.

I have made this statement before in the House, but it is worth emphasising that the area in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park which is in greatest danger from an oil spill is the far north section, undoubtedly because of the sheer isolation of that part of my electorate. Obviously, if an oil spill occurred off Cairns, all requisite plans could be carried out. Cairns has an international airport and an international port: ships could assist in an emergency such as this, and planes could bring in everything that is required to mop up an oil spill.

But, if a spill occurs further north than Cooktown, one is talking about areas which are very sparsely populated. Lockhart River and Portland Roads would be the largest communities on the eastern side of Cape York. They are very small communities and certainly would not even be able to provide the manpower, if I may use that word, to assist in such an operation, let alone provide all the things that one needs, such as solvents. Yet that is the part of the reef that is most pristine; that is the part of the reef that is probably in a state closest to the state that it has been in for thousands of years.

That is a great danger. I say that quite simply and easily in this chamber. It is not a criticism of the government, because it is a problem that probably cannot be solved. It can only be solved, I suggest, by the preventative measures that are set out in Ships of Shame. It can only be solved by those sorts of preventative measures. I am not saying that if an oil spoil does occur there is nothing that can be done about it, but, because of all the factors that I put to the Main Committee earlier, it is going to be a lot harder to contain and it is going to be a lot harder to mop up. As has been mentioned before, the bill does contain amendments for penalties for breaches of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act, and I support those amendments.

In the time that I have got left, I want to talk a little bit about the chairman and the authority itself. Presently, the authority consists of a chairman, Dr Ian McPhail, and two other members. The bill proposes the expansion of the membership of the authority to include a member appointed to represent the interests of Aboriginal communities adjacent to the marine park, and I certainly support that. I am pleased to welcome Dr McPhail to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I am pleased that, in a change from past practice, he will be based in Townsville. I have been a long-term advocate for the case for locating a GBRMPA senior executive near the reef, in order to foster productive relations with the agencies that manage the reef.

Dr McPhail has a wide range of experience in both state and federal environmental matters. His most recent position was that of chief executive officer of the South Australian Department of Education and Children's Services. He was the first chief executive of the federal Environment Protection Agency, and a member of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. He was educated at the University of Canterbury in New Zealand before being awarded a doctorate by the University of New England. His is obviously a very good appointment.

If these amendments are passed, as I am sure they will be, Dr McPhail will now be joined by an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person. This is not tokenism, Mr Deputy Speaker, as the previous speaker suggests—far from it. No doubt there has been extensive Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander visitation up and down the Queensland coast, including traditional hunting and fishing, for thousands of years. For thousands of years, Aboriginal people have fished and gathered shellfish and clams in the area we now know as the Great Barrier Reef. The area was rich with traditional food such as dugong and turtle.

Evidence of the long-term involvement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Torres Strait has been part of a little bit of the controversy about Hinchinbrook Channel. There were stone fish traps that were thousands of years old in that area, and other areas of the coast. They now have been preserved, because of the actions of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner). Those fish traps are a living example of the long-term connection that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have with the Great Barrier Reef.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people visited Cairns, Green Island and what we now call Fitzroy Island to hunt and fish. They have got a close connection. So, of course, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be involved in the management of the park. Of course they have got a lot of knowledge to provide. It is a shame that we have not tapped that resource in the past. That is the reason for this proposal—not some sort of tokenism. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have had years of experience in dealing with the marine environment, and perhaps we might learn a little bit from them. I certainly welcome that amendment and look forward to the appointment of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person.

In the last few minutes that I have got, I want to talk a bit about the different areas of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park in my electorate. As I indicated earlier, there are concerns and different views about the Cairns zone. I am not a scientific expert so I do not pretend to have all knowledge in these things, but a lot of people approach me and say that the Cairns zone has trouble with being overfished. I am not saying that that is right; I am saying that people say that to me.

There are complaints about over-visitation. On any morning, from Trinity Wharf in Cairns, there will be close to hundreds of tour ships—big ones, little ones—going out to the Great Barrier Reef. There are certainly a lot of people who go and that is welcome; that is why we have got tourism in Cairns. But we have just got to be very careful of that Cairns zone. There is the question of sewerage and water quality, and I am very pleased to see in the annual report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority that there is constant monitoring of water quality, and that that is something it is going to look to in the future.

One of the ways that we might be able to deal with this problem is to look at the far northern section of the Great Barrier Reef. I think that, to some extent, we have got to look at developing areas for tourism away from the Cairns zone. The far northern zone is a bit underdeveloped—if I can use that word—in terms of tourism, yet it has one of the most beautiful parts of the reef and it certainly has some of the best coral for viewing in the outer reef. I am pleased to note that the authority has a review of management for the far northern section, which began in 1993-94. Critical issues which are being addressed in the review are: ensuring that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander interests are reflected in the management of the marine park; defining the recreation and tourism settings and use levels which are to be provided in the far northern section; and developing mechanisms for integrated planning and management of the far northern section and adjacent coastal areas.

It is also pleasing to know that in April 1994, with the assistance of the Cape York Land Council, there was a meeting between the authority and the indigenous custodians on Cape York. This is very exciting. The development of that far northern zone—in terms of its protection, the involvement with our indigenous people, and the potential of very managed and sustainable ecotourism and other tourism operations—is very exciting. It certainly will become part of the sustained development in the future of Cape York Peninsula.

Finally, I referred earlier to the Torres Strait and we cannot forget the strait, even though it is outside the authority. There has been controversy about possible pollution from the Ok Tedi mine in Papua-New Guinea. There was a base-line study which, if it reached any conclusion at all, suggested that there might not be as much pollution as some people thought. But people in the Torres Strait, who know the area and know the reef, have the feeling that there is some contamination, especially in food and marine life in the strait. That is something that we have got to keep our eye on all the time. The Ok Tedi mine is obviously part of Papua-New Guinea's economic development, but if it does affect the Torres Strait it affects the food supply, and that would be disastrous. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Looking at the various amendments to Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, I want to speak at length on the issue of credit cards to certain other agencies. But in responding to the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) and his remarks about whether or not this was a tokenistic measure, might I say that the test for that—and I hope that his words will prove to be true—is the person who is appointed. Of course, if the government continues to identify `spokesman for the Cape York Land Council' as a person who happens to live in Sydney and who appears on television frequently, saying how he knows everything about what is going on there, then I think—and I am not saying that is the person likely to be appointed—the charge of tokenism may have some merit.

PARA.TAB: Of course, if a person is selected with genuine traditional links and with some historical capacity to deal with this matter, it will not be tokenistic. I just make this as a comment; it is not a criticism. We accept the fundamental principle of what the government is trying to do. I put the honourable member on notice, since he has raised the question of tokenism—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't raise the question.

—The honourable member did raise the question. He said that it is not a tokenistic thing and, having put the matter on the record, the honourable member has to make sure it is not tokenistic by ensuring the appointment of someone who will make the sort of contribution to the care of the reef that we all desire. It is a simple comment but, as I said, at least one member of your party criticises a number of people whom we see from time to time for their claimed spokesmanship for various groups within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island community, when, in fact, their links, to say the least, are tenuous and come under the category of the Aboriginal industry. It is the government's choice. I sincerely hope, in the interests of the reef, that the choice is a good one. I leave the matter at that.

PARA.TAB: It is notable that, within this legislation, the government extends the use of credit cards to the Heritage Commission, the National Parks and Wildlife Service, the Australian Sports Commission and the Australian Sports Drug Agency. Since it got a mention, I am tempted to talk about drugs in sport from the point of view of a member of the horseracing industry. I still find it a bit funny that we can read in the paper that at half-time someone went rushing inside for a pain-killing injection so they could come back onto the sporting field. In the racing industry, if we were even to mention that, let alone try it, we would be doing long terms of disqualification.

I will just take a second longer of the time to say that I find it a great peculiarity that humans are allowed to touch themselves up and admit it in the newspaper. Maybe human competition should look closely at the racing industry. As an administrator in that business, whilst I believe we have to look more sensibly at the therapeutic drug, I am violently opposed to any activity that kills pain signals. Firstly, I think it is stupid and not in the interest of the participant, be it four-legged or two-legged. Pain is there as signal that something is hurt and the athlete should not run. Many of our young and elite athletes are seen only short-term because they do those sorts of things. I will not touch any more on that; I am really stretching the rules of relevance. I think it is an issue that this parliament might one day address.

The point is that those bodies are going to receive access to credit cards. An interesting fact that I want to draw to honourable members' attention is that, on 20 March 1986, I brought a private member's bill to the parliament for the prompt payment of government debt. This is recorded in Hansard, commencing on page 1680. It is also interesting to note that recently the ACT Legislative Assembly passed legislation in that direction. Maybe it is a fault of politics that, instead of supporting that legislation, the government at that time chose an alternate method to address this problem, which was quite real, and that alternative was the credit card. In other words, certain people making certain purchases for the government could produce a credit card. Presumably, that works similarly to the sorts of credit cards that we have. The supplier can literally bank the document and that achieves, without doubt, prompt payment—about the absence of which we had grave criticism at the time.

One of the members in the House is at pains to bring up the performance of the Victorian government these days. Of course, in that 1986 speech, I drew attention to the circumstances that existed in Victoria at the time under Mr Cain where, in fact, one fellow had gone broke because the state government owed him $100,000 and he could not get the money. But I also gave a number of examples relating to the Commonwealth and, of course, pointed out that the enactment of this sort of legislation in the United States in 1983 had changed the situation from one where auditors had reported that at least one-third of federal government accounts in the United States were paid after the due date and late to one where the simple proposal we had, and that the Americans had passed, was that if you did not pay on time you paid interest.

We made it, in our legislation, that that had to come from the current budget allocation to that department. We had two reasons for that: firstly, it did not commit the government to additional expenditure, which was a constitutional situation; and, secondly, we thought it highly appropriate that a department whose laxity was frequently the only reason that it did not pay on time—or else it eked its budget out a bit through the money market or something—would pay a penalty, and that it might then find some of its other expenditures reduced.

The introduction of the credit card has not really been a practical measure. Whilst the opposition is not opposing the extension of this provision to other government agencies, we remind the government of the words of the Auditor-General, who, in fact, has pointed out some rather outrageous uses of these cards and has expressed the view that they limit prudential management. What we proposed, through prompt payment of government debt, kept in place the proper prudential arrangements by which government revenue is protected and expenditure controlled.

One would issue an order and do all the proper things that ensured that money was not spent on speedboats and fur coats and a few of the other things that appeared in that list, and one would have a proper control and approval process. But, if the supplier were not paid within the normal trading arrangements, the government agency or department would be automatically eligible to pay interest on the outstandings—which I think we identified at that time as being over $100,000 at the Commonwealth Bank. In fact, we had pharmacist at that time who had to borrow $20,000 to pay his tax, when the PBS owed him $60,000. That seems a bit unreasonable.

Of course, these people have never had their problems addressed with credit cards, because PBS does not go running around giving pharmacists credit card payment. It only really touched on the lesser sort of genuine trade deals, whereas the legislation that I proposed was all-encompassing. If the government had trade debts with anybody, it had to pay them on time or at least pay interest, which was the due compensation for the overdraft that that particular supplier might have.

As I say, we are not standing in the road of the extension of this process. I would like to remind the House that the scheme has not been successful: it is not universal and it is too simply subject to fraud—whereas a process is now enacted in the ACT as proposed by us back in 1986. Anybody who checks the historical record will find that the announcement of the use of credit cards came shortly after. In fact, all the government had to do—and, of course, this is a lesson for both sides of politics—was occasionally recognise a good idea when it came from the opposition. Had the government picked up our proposal, it would then not have had the embarrassment or the concern that it has had in the past over the abuse of credit cards, and it would have achieved a prompt payment regime.
In my speech in 1986 I made some remarks that have not lost their relevance. I referred to the reasons why we favoured the introduction of this legislation. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons are numerous and include inefficiency and a sometimes callous disregard by public servants as to the cash flow problems of Australian business. No doubt one of the principal reasons is the dramatic overspending inherent in Keating Budgets which has increased the Federal Government's indebtedness by $20,000m—
to make that remark contemporary I would now say $85,000 million—
and has seen interest charges to the Commonwealth—
in other words, public debt interest—

double to almost $7,000m and in that process move from the fifth highest to the second highest direct expenditure item in the Budget. Clearly there is now good reason for the Government to wish to gain interest-free credit from its creditors.

The point to be made there is that that process of government borrowing to pay, using our children as security, rather than meet its expenditure with its revenue, has progressed to the point where the federal total debt now is about $100,000 million, up from $15,000 million at the conclusion of the Fraser government. The interest bill, at $8.6 billion, is only about $1 billion behind the government's expenditures on education. On the forward estimates for 1997-98, the government's expenditure on education is predicted to be $10,000 million and its expenditure on interest roughly the same.

PARA.TAB: By the use of credit cards the delayed payment has to an extent been removed, as a means of funding the budget. I made reference in another part of the speech to the fact that, when one talks about deficits, the shifting of some substantial indebtedness on behalf of the government by a simple month changes the deficit because it is talked about in the following year and not in the current. The real issue is that it is time the government recognised that it is not appropriate to continue extending this credit card arrangement. It is not the way that governments should do business. It has been identified and proven by the Auditor-General as a means by which fraudulent purchases can be made—and if not fraudulent, then certainly highly questionable.

The solution was to accept our position, which is still our position and still exists in our small business policy, to require government by law to pay its debts on time to whomsoever they are owed, and otherwise to pay interest. That allows for all the prudential procedures to be retained and for people to receive their money on time. Some in the pharmacy profession and others, as I have pointed out, have very substantial debts accruing to them on a monthly basis under such systems as the PBS.

That is the conclusion of my contribution. The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), who will speak next in the debate, may want to try to defend the Cain government for selling the trams and a few of those things, and tell me that really and truly it was a great payer. But whilst he rises to the debate with certain current people there, he has to remember that the two things that were so inherent in Melbourne and Victoria in general were the trams and the Victorians' pride that they were the commercial centre of the world. The previous state government sold the trams and caused the creation of that wonderful saying: `What is the capital of Victoria? Answer: $2.'

I think it can be said of the present administration that it fixed a lot of that. I read that it is about to buy the trams back and I give it full credit for that. It has reinstated the pride of Victorians in being the commercial centre and enabled them to have some pride in their city. That, to me, was very important for Victorians because, unlike us Western Australians, they did not have very much else going for them. But they did have their pride and they had some substantiation because of their commercial practices over the century as being leaders in that field. Suddenly it all collapsed around them because their government lost all their money.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to offend Victorians but I think you meant that Melburnians saw themselves as the commercial capital of Australia rather than the world, as you said.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. That is true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We still are the commercial capital. I have no fear about that, even with the present government, because there is still quite a good deal of commercial business down there. He has not got rid of it all; all of it has not shifted to Queensland yet.

PARA.TAB: The member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) attacked the government for the time it takes to pay bills. Before I came into parliament I was in small business myself, and it was quite common for it to take at least 120 days to get the money out of some people. I always remember—and one of the reasons I am in politics is because of this one case—a person who owed me $1,000 in 1976. He had a BMW, a flat up in Surfers, and he was a member of the Liberal Party. So I must thank him because that debt problem is one of the reasons I am here today. For a small businessman $1,000 was a lot of money back then. My family was living on handouts from the church while I was establishing my business. So I know what it is like to be owed a lot of money.

However, that is not too much to do with this bill. The honourable member for O'Connor also mentioned the balance of payments. I think it is opportune for me to ask—since we are talking about debt and credit card debt—who owes this money, who owes this thousands of millions of dollars. It is not every man, woman and child in Australia; it is mainly the businesses of Australia; it is mainly the supporters of the opposition. Seventy per cent of all overseas debt is owed by the Coles Myers, the national banks and—

TALK.START.PARA: —Alan Bond.

—The Alan Bonds, yes, and all the people who bring in all these goods. Those sorts of people owe all this debt. It is not you and I that owe the debt; they do. The rest of the money—the other 25 per cent or so—is owed by state government instrumentalities. The Commonwealth does not owe very much at all. We were actually buying back our debt not long ago from the Japanese, and they would not sell it to us because they were getting a good interest rate that they knew would be paid.

PARA.TAB: All right, our debt might have gone up a little bit but we have not created the debt; it is the companies, the big businesses, who have created it. It is about time we pointed this out to people, instead of having this ongoing attack on the Labor government from the opposition saying that each one of us owes $7,000, $8,000 or $10,000. I can assure honourable members that I do not owe it and none of my family owes that sort of money.

One of the items in the bill that we are considering, the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill, is the appointment of an Aboriginal person to represent the communities on the Great Barrier Marine Park Authority. In my view, this is a great step forward. I do not know why it was not done before; it was probably just an oversight. However, I am quite certain that whoever is appointed will make a tremendous contribution to that organisation.

It is not just the actual reef; it is the fringing coast land and everything that comes from the reef that comes under the authority, and I am quite certain that the skill and the knowledge that the Aborigines have in regard to this area will be passed on to us. I am quite certain that we can learn something about it from their thousands of years of experience.

While I am talking about the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, I know that its head, Graeme Kelleher, left just before Christmas. I have known Graeme for quite a long time, and he was one of the ultimate public servants. One could never pick which way he was going and what the left hand or the right hand was doing, but he seemed to juggle it all through and get his way very smartly. He was a very good operator who set the foundations for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority very well. A new person has been appointed, and that person will have a good foundation to work on. It is a good organisation which could be a model for other organisations in the way it is run and the work that it does.

Another measure in this particular bill increases the powers of inspectors, et cetera, for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. There is a huge amount of poaching going on; I am quite certain of that. I have no proof or anything like that but one only has to look at what happens in Victorian waters in regard to the abalone. It has been estimated that about $30 million of abalone is poached off Victoria and in Bass Strait. If that is going on there, I am quite certain there is a lot of abuse of the resources going on over the length of the barrier reef, and I am quite pleased that extra resources have been put into policing it and making certain that it is not overexploited.

We heard yesterday from the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) in relation to what has happened to Australia's tuna industry, how its value has dropped from $60 million to $18 million or something like that. It was a huge drop and that has happened because of greed and overexploitation of that resource. I am pleased that no-one has found any use for coral; otherwise you would have the North Broken Hills of this world with their woodchippers—I should not say that—in there exploiting that resource. I am very pleased that this is a World Heritage area, that it is locked up and we cannot drill it, mine it or do anything to it. It is there as the greatest living organism on the whole earth and it should be left that way.

The other area that I would like to mention briefly is the one paragraph in relation to the Norfolk Island Act. As the chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories, I cannot say too much about Norfolk Island because we do have a report coming out, but the names there have been changed from president and deputy president to speaker and deputy speaker. I do not know why this has happened. It has been that way for many years. I just wonder if it has anything to do about the debate over the republic and things like that. Norfolk Island is a very interesting island, and I will have a lot more to say in the future about what is happening there, the way the government works over there and some of the problems that they are experiencing. Our report in relation to transport and freight to the island territories—not only Norfolk Island but also the Indian Ocean territories—is finished, and we hope to bring it down in the House in the next month or so.

In the annual report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority for 1993-94 there are a few areas that I would like to comment on. One of the areas that I notice is the number of permit applications received and the huge increase in the number of permits issued, up from 500 in 1992-93 to about 900 in 1993-94. Most of these permits have gone to tourist programs. I am not sure whether it is No. 1 of our tourist attractions but it must be one of the major tourist attractions in Australia. It probably is No. 1, and I think Uluru is after that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reef.

—The reef is. But the authority has issued a huge increase in the number of tourist permits. I think maybe it should stop for a while and have a look at the number of permits that have been issued and what sort of pressures there are on the reef. I know the marine park authority has quite a number of staff looking at this but it might be time to call a halt to all of that. We have got high speed catamarans which take 300 or 400 passengers a day from Cairns out to the reef. We are possibly putting too much pressure on the reef. I am no expert but it seems strange to me that there has been such a huge increase in the number of permits. Once again we are seeing an increase in the crown-of-thorns starfish. Whether there is a connection or not no-one knows. In 1985 when I was on the environment committee we did an inquiry on the crown-of-thorns starfish and there was no conclusive evidence whether pollution or tourist pressure exacerbated the situation. I notice that recently there have been signs of an increase, so another plague or another outbreak could be about to start. A huge number of juvenile crown-of-thorns starfish are there and no-one knows what causes it.

PARA.TAB: I know there has been a large amount of research done on this. It is ongoing. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and AIMS are doing quite a bit of research. One of the things we should do is slow things down and find out what the reason is for the outbreaks. People have cored the Great Barrier Reef with drills. They have actually seen that, over thousands of years, there have been plagues of starfish. It looks as though they are getting more and more frequent. If we do not use the reef correctly, if we abuse the Barrier Reef, we will certainly affect the tourist dollars that come into Australia and our reputation for looking after one of our greatest tourist attractions. A report in Search in April 1994 says:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether or not the increase in starfish numbers represents the early stages of another major outbreak for the GBR is unknown. At this stage the numbers of starfish are small, but the GBRMPA is taking the current situation very seriously because:
.coral cover on reefs in the Cairns to Cooktown area is returning to levels capable of supporting large numbers of starfish;
.there was a 17 year interval between the start of the first and second outbreaks and, if that periodicity is repeated, another outbreak is due around 1996 . . .
As I said before, the reasons for the outbreaks are still unknown. The report continues:

However, if human influences are responsible for causing or exacerbating outbreaks, the conditions for outbreak initiation are probably even more conducive now than they were 15 years ago given the increased usage of the Reef and surrounding coastal areas . . .

That is why I am concerned about this large increase in permits. We do not know why these crown-of-thorns outbreaks happen but they could be because of human pollution. We all know how that occurs: look at the islands and the number of people going there, the sewage, the waste, and also what comes out of the rivers that flow out onto the Barrier Reef.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) mentioned the Fly River in New Guinea and the problems that that could cause the reef. In our report in 1985 we actually mentioned that as well. One of our recommendations read:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government consult with the Papua New Guinea Government on the need for an environmental assessment of the Ok Tedi mine giving particular regard to the possibility of the pollution of reefs in the Torres Strait and the northern Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

As I said, that was in 1985. I do not know what has happened there. I recall a retaining dam at the Ok Tedi mine broke and huge amounts of sluice and tailings went into the river. I have seen photographs of it. One of these days I hope to get there and have a look at it just to see how bad that pollution is. I do not know whether there have been any studies done on whether it is affecting our reef; I do not think so. But it is something that we should look at because it is important. Those currents obviously must come out and affect the northern reef.

PARA.TAB: The other area that I would like to mention quickly in relation to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is the ocean rescue 2000 program that has started. To me, this is a great program. Even in Frankston we have got signs on our drains saying, `This drain goes into Port Phillip Bay. Don't litter,' et cetera. Simple little things like that have gone into the psyche of many people. That has come from this particular organisation which is being run from GBRMPA. I am quite pleased that it is actually being done. I would like more resources to be put into this so that it can work closer with the schools. More education with our children

SPEECH.PARA: is needed. Our children are light-years ahead of us in relation to pollution matters but I think we could still increase the amount of education that goes into that issue. I have often said that all we have got to do is to hang on to our environment until the year 2000 and then we will not have any problems. The kids who follow us or the other people who follow us into parliament, et cetera, are all environmentally conscious. What we have got left, I can assure you, they will hang on to.

PARA.TAB: While I am talking about things to hang on to, I want to refer to an article that I recently read in the American Time magazine about endangered animals. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: Scores of animals will be extinct by the year 2000. You have not heard of most of them but they will still be missed. Abbott's booby, which breeds only on Christmas Island, looks done for. So does Australia's gastric breeding frog.

When I came back I made some inquiries because I was worried about the Abbott's booby. I have been to Christmas Island and I have seen the birds; they are beautiful birds. In 1983, the then Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment did a report on the preservation of the Abbott's booby. According to the latest information that I have, the pairs have increased, although the bird is still on the endangered list.

PARA.TAB: They are very slow breeding birds; they only breed every couple of years. Because of the really harsh mining that went on on Christmas Island many years ago—it is still going on today, but in a limited way,—a lot of trees and ground cover were knocked over. The Abbott's booby only breeds in the tops of certain trees and the wind is blowing the chicks out of the trees so the young are not surviving. If this article in Time is correct, I would urge the minister, who is here, to ask whether something could be done to make certain that we do not lose this particular bird. I would hate it if we lost another animal. It is something that we should have a good look at and make certain that there is a breeding program or something to try to build up the numbers of this particular bird.

People might ask whether it is a bit crass to look after one bird when we have killed hundreds of mammals in the past and they are dying out every day. I always look at it this way: we cannot just make these things. We cannot get a computer to spit out a bird or anything like that. These birds are one of a kind and they have got to be looked after. They are very important. I would like our government to make certain that this article in Time is not correct and that we are doing all we can to preserve this beautiful creature.

This is a bill that covers lots of areas. I am pleased to speak on anything to do with the environment and I will do all I can to make certain our environment is looked after, even in the woodchipping area. I will still go in and protect trees, and I have no problems in standing up here and saying that. While I still have one minute and 58 seconds, I must mention that I visited a woodchipping mill in Victoria. Because I am a bit biased about this issue, I thought I had better go and have a look at a mill. I visited an operation in Geelong owned by a mob called Midway. Right in front of the gate they had placed the worst looking truckload of logs I have ever seen. It had obviously been placed there as a bit of a stunt. There were some offcuts from a mill which had also been placed there as a bit of a stunt. I also saw a pile of logs 200 yards long. Now, I am no expert but they all looked like sawlogs to me. They were going through the chipper and the pile would have been about 30 feet high.

As we were walking around the place, I saw they had a sawmill there. The idea was to put in this $700,000 saw, saw all the sawlogs out of any log that came through and then put the rest through the chipper. Being an old turner and fitter, I thought I would go and have a look at this. The thing had not been used for months. All the slides were rusty and all the chains still had the paint on them. It was just a big con job.

I have no problems in saying that and I have said it in the open because what they are putting through there is a con job. I said to Robert Bain, who was with me—and you can ask him about this—`How long since this has been used?'. He called out to a guy in the front, who did not know who I was, and he said, `Oh, it has not been used for six weeks.' No-one can tell me that over a six-week period there has not been a log put through that chip mill that did not have a sawlog in it. They were putting through hundreds a day. If we are looking at woodchipping, let us have a look at this Midway mob down at Geelong. That company actually got an increase in its export licence and I do not believe it should have.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I do not want unduly to take up the time of the Main Committee; however, I would like to make a comment on the Abbott's booby. Whilst I have not read the article, I would be very surprised if the assertions which are made within it, as has been reported by my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), are anywhere near correct.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Nature Conservation Agency has put in place a very detailed program which addresses concerns about the preservation of the Abbott's booby. The program has been very successful, partly because we have been able to isolate the breeding areas of the bird within the national park on Christmas Island. For those of you who have no knowledge of Christmas Island, I should point out that slightly less than 70 per cent of Christmas Island is now a national park.

The honourable member for Dunkley mentioned the mining operations on Christmas Island. Those operations are isolated to the working over of old stockpiles. No new mining is taking place, and there are huge stockpiles. We are in the process of negotiating an extension of the mining lease, but the rainforest area—the national park—is preserved. The primary purpose of that preservation, apart from protecting the habitats of crabs and other such creatures, and obviously protecting the unique nature of the rainforest timber and the rainforest itself, is the preservation of the Abbott's booby.

I commend the foresight of my colleague in bringing this matter to our attention, but I assure him that the Australian Nature Conservation Agency is doing an extremely effective job. The people who are involved in the preservation of the Abbott's booby should be congratulated because not only have they been practising good science, but they have actually been helping to develop what is potentially a very important and significant tourism aspect of Christmas Island—the national park and all that is in it, including the Abbott's booby.

I thank all honourable members for participating in the debate. Obviously, I have not agreed with all that has been put forward, but I do not think now is the time to split hairs or to engage in some active diatribe, which I might want to do on some other occasion. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a great deal of pleasure in making a few comments in relation to the annual report for 1993-94 of the Family Law Council. Before doing so I would like to make a comment about the Main Committee. As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure, and having been a dissenter in the original report that gave rise to the creation of the Main Committee, I must say that I have changed my mind. The Main Committee is a success.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I would like to commend the use of the Main Committee for these `take note' debates. Bearing in mind the large number of reports and other tabled documents that are on the Notice Paper at any time, this is a tremendous opportunity for members to have their say, whereas before the opportunity may not have arisen. As a member of that committee, and bearing in mind that the committee will be reviewing the operations of the various standing and sessional orders that were created or changed last year to accommodate the government's response to the committee's report About time, I think it is a pertinent time to commend the operations of the Main Committee.

My interest in this particular aspect of the activities of the Family Law Council arises from the fact that my electorate has probably the greatest concentration of families with children, particularly young children, in the country. It is an outer metropolitan mortgage belt area, and an area of phenomenal growth. The city of Wanneroo, which is the main municipality in my electorate, is the fastest growing municipality in the country. The growth is quite astonishing. When I go to community meetings and the like in the newer areas I am astonished that each time I go I find there are quite a few additional changes.

In particular, there are enormous numbers of young families coming into an area where there are the usual difficulties, created in the first instance by the establishment of a new home and the financial difficulties and constraints that that particular activity generates, and where additional problems are created by the on-costs that the federal Labor government has slapped onto young families raising children. It is a disappointment in my particular area that the increase in interest rates is hurting families very badly. In many cases these are people who, since the last quarter of 1994, have seen an increase of around $100 per month in their mortgage repayments. Ordinarily that might not seem to be a significant amount of money, but to people who are balancing a household budget and where every single dollar counts, $100 additional a month is a staggering amount of money. It means, effectively, that my constituents have to deduct that expenditure from other areas.

I can assure members present that, if they were to go around my electorate in the new areas, they would see evidence of those difficulties. Probably it would be the same in other new areas—perhaps not so much in Canberra, because of the very high level of average household income here, but certainly in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, the Gold Coast and Adelaide. In all these new metropolitan conurbation areas where there are large developments of housing, one can drive around and see that many of these younger families do not have carpets, do not have curtains and do not have gardens, because they cannot afford the often minimal expenditure required. They cannot afford to do the basic things like putting in a driveway to a carport, or putting in the bare minimum of garden landscaping that would allow the children to be able to recreate in the back garden. It costs a lot of money; and at present, thanks to the drought conditions in the metropolitan area of Perth, we have water restrictions as well. These are quite necessary restrictions, but again they impact on those people who are endeavouring to establish their new homes and new lawns so as to be able to have a play area for their children. In many cases, that may be the only play area that the children have available to them within a reasonable distance.

The impact of high interest rates is a significant problem to my constituents—in particular, the impact on families. We know the old expression about love flying out of the window when family financial problems arise. The report of the Family Law Council, which I will come to shortly, deals with aspects of the activities of that council, which is created under the act, to look at a variety of features, activities and circumstances revolving around the operations of the Family Law Act. It is fair to say that, where there is the sort of financial pressure that my constituents would have, thanks to the government's high interest rates and taxes generally, there are obvious significant effects on relations between the parents. Probably members of every family in the country, somewhere in their relationships, through their relatives or even their own direct experience, are touched by the problems associated with divorce and separation.

On behalf of my constituents I can only urge the federal Labor government to reconsider very seriously any suggestion to introduce a carbon tax or any other impost on goods and services, because my particular constituents would be affected worst. They are invariably people who work in the city or in the inner Perth area. They have to commute to work. No matter how they travel to work, whether in their own family vehicle or on public transport, the imposition of a carbon tax would naturally add to their costs. It would also add to the costs of providing the bare essentials for the family home, in order to nourish their children and to provide them with even minimal leisure activities such as many families consider are part of the Australian way of life. The imposition of a carbon tax is no more than the imposition of a goods and services tax of a different type, and it comes with no other reforms to the taxation system to ameliorate the on-costs of such a tax to normal household operations.

I turn now to some of the details of the report of the Family Law Council. This is the annual report of a body that is created under the Family Law Act, under which it is given the functions of advising and making recommendations to the minister concerning the working of the Family Law Act 1975 and other legislation relating to family law, the working of legal aid in relation to family law and any other matter relating to family law.

There has been in recent times an inquiry by the Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Family Law into the operation and effectiveness of the child support scheme. During the 1993-94 year, the council made a submission in relation to that matter. It made a number of points, some of which are very pertinent to the current public debate about the effectiveness of the agency and the legislation within which the agency operates. It looked at four broad areas in the operations of the agency—the child support formula, administrative issues and problems, extension of the scheme's application and other matters. It suggested that the existing formula for the assessment of child support and its variants did not ensure that:

SPEECH.PARA: .children have their proper needs to the extent that it does not distinguish between children of different ages once certain minimum proper needs calculated according to age have been met;
.the duty to maintain any one child is not of lower priority than duty to maintain any other child . . .
.the duty to maintain a child is secondary to the payer's own realistic commitments first being met;
.parents with a like capacity provide like amounts of child support because it is `income' based rather than `financial resource' based—

and so on. Those comments are very pertinent. We have heard in the public debate significant, serious concerns from around the country in relation to the operations of the agency and, in particular, to the application of the formula.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with one other matter. One of the things that have been of concern to the Family Law Council is the review of Family Court penalties. The acting Attorney-General, in 1993, wrote to the council about recommendation 59 in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Family Law, that the Family Law Council conduct a review of penalties applied by the Family Court in cases of non-compliance with orders and injunctions which come before it. It was asked to report urgently on that matter.

The details of a particular case in my electorate in the application of a penalty in relation to a convicted contempt of the Family Court in Western Australia are absolutely shocking. I must keep the details of the people confidential. This particular instance related to the spending of a large amount of money that was subject to—and I think is still subject to—a Family Court determination in relation to the wife in a relationship. The amount of money spent—something like $99,000—was considered a very serious contempt by the Family Court. In his judgment the judge made the following finding:

SPEECH.PARA: In my view there is no doubt that the wife has contravened the order—
that was the restraining order—

There is no doubt in my mind, for the reasons I have given, that she did so knowingly and that the contravention does involve the flagrant challenge to the authority of the Court. The order could not have been clearer. The order in simple terms, was "Don't touch the money". The wife acted deliberately. It is difficult to imagine a set of circumstances that would involve a more flagrant challenge to the authority of this Court or any others. For the reasons given by me, I propose to record a finding that the wife is guilty of a contempt of the order as alleged.

There was an occurrence similar in some aspects to this case, although not quite as serious, where a man in a relationship had attempted to conceal an amount of money from the Family Court in terms of a settlement. That particular person, who will remain anonymous, said the amount was a secret investment worth about $70,000. He was convicted and sentenced to three years imprisonment. Here is a situation where a person who has concealed an amount of money, bearing in mind that the money was still at the disposal of the court in the final analysis, gets a three-year sentence; whereas in this particular instance we have a woman who has flagrantly defied the order of the court, committed a serious contempt of the court and ended up with a community service order of 40 hours.

PARA.TAB: The irony is that the court's determination sought a pre-sentence report which concluded that the woman was unsuitable for a community service order for a variety of reasons, not the least of which was that it considered she showed no remorse for her particular act. I am not aware whether any part of the money that had been expended by the woman has been recovered.

This serious contempt of court being punished by a community service order of 40 hours—I think an order that has now been fulfilled—gave the man who was the complainant in this matter the obvious feeling that he had been dealt with in a most unjust way compared with the other case.

Many people around the country allege that there is a bias in the Family Court against men in settlements. That is an unfortunate side effect of the application of the Family Law Act and, in particular, the application of penalties within the context of the Family Law Act. The joint select committee concluded in its recommendation to the then acting Attorney-General, and the Family Law Council concluded in making a request for there to be a long-term inquiry, that, on the basis of experience with other studies, especially intractable access projects, it was desirable that a review should be conducted on a long-term basis which followed matters through into the future rather than through an examination of past cases. The council was of the view that a short-term study would not be particularly helpful.

I can only support that finding. In the case of my constituent it is an outrageous injustice. There is an absolute necessity for a long-term inquiry into the penalties associated with the Family Court. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Snow) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 8 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1635 (Hansard, 16 November 1994, page 3657), what class of persons were granted intermediate rate pensions between 1990 and 1993 given the discrepancy between the numbers of recipients at different stages and those who have died.

(2) How many of the widows who did not receive a war widows' pension after the death of their spouse between 1 January 1990 and 30 December 1993 (a) did not apply or (b) were not granted the pension for reasons other than rejection of claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is no specific class of persons who are entitled to the intermediate rate. An Australian veteran, a member of the Australian Defence Force, an Australian member of a Peacekeeping Force, or an Australian mariner, may be eligible for the intermediate rate if:
the degree of incapacity from the person's war-caused or defence-caused disability or disabilities is determined to be at least 70%; or
the person has suffered or is suffering from pulmonary tuberculosis, and is receiving or is entitled to receive a disability pension at the general rate; and

the incapacity from the person's accepted disability or disabilities alone renders the person incapable of undertaking remunerative work otherwise than on a part-time basis or intermittently (unable to undertake or continue to undertake 50% or more of normal time or 20 hours or more per week); and

the person is, by reason of his or her incapacity from accepted disability or disabilities alone, prevented from continuing to undertake remunerative work and suffers a loss of income or earnings which the person would not suffer if free from that incapacity.
Between 1 January 1990 and 31 December 1993 a total of 428 persons were granted the intermediate rate of disability pension. Annual grants in these three years were as under:
(2)(a) To date 32 widows have not been granted a war widow's pension after the death of their spouse. Of this number 14 have not lodged a claim.

(2)(b) The remaining 18 cases were all rejected. Of these, four are awaiting a decision on their appeals and there were no cases of claims being withdrawn, or where the claimants died before determination.
